title.narrative: Training4GreenJobs

description.narrative:
The Train4greenjobs project stimulates collaboration between TVET education and Ugandan private enterprises in two mountainous areas with high horticultural potential: the West Nile (around Arua) and Western Regions (Fort Portal). It will (1) support educational institutes in organising their education according to labour market needs, (2) develop a pilot (focus on West Nile province) and set an example for horticulture training development from which others in Uganda can learn, and (3) develop practical guidance for strengthening horticulture training in the country. In Train4greenjobs the focus will be on the (seed)potato value chain and other relevant value chains to be selected.
The goal is to develop a truly practical, labour-market oriented Diploma in horticulture at Innovative Institute for Agriculture, Business and Capacity Building IABC) and Mountains of the Moon (MMU) and to extract and share lessons learnt in this process with Muni University and MMU for developing their horticulture BSc and with ADRAA Agricultural College (AAC) for further developing their horticulture Certificate.
The teachers of all institutes will participate in learning how to apply curriculum improvement at different levels and to establish an integral learning line connection with the pilot diploma level. Zone College and MMUM will develop capacities to support the curriculum adjustment process in other areas and value chains in Uganda. Target groups are:
- The staff of participating educational institutes making their education more labour market oriented - Staff of Dutch green vocational institutes gaining international educational experience - Students of which at least 30% women of all participating educational institutes.

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: A. TVET/HE organisations perform better their core tasks, firmly embedded in their environment
A.E.5. Number of curricula for degree, non-degree and short courses revised/newly developed

description.narrative: Degree: bachelor's, master's and doctorate Non degree: Certificate and diploma

comment.narrative: 19-01-2021: We are working on this. | 19-01-2021: We are still working on this.

title.narrative: A.O.10. Diversity in management and teaching staff (i.e. balance in junior/senior staff, women/men, minorities)

description.narrative: please enclose stories of change or examples of best practices

actual.value: Currently staff involved in the OKP is male dominated. It will be hard to change this as staff at the institutions is mainly male. At management level women are relatively better represented with the Director if the Arua IABC college and the vice chancellor of Muni university being female. Through our gender and diversity activities we will try to make a meaningful contribution to increasing attention to gender issues and the need for representation of the diversity of the students in the staff component.

title.narrative: A.O.1. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the knowledge institution

description.narrative: please enclose stories of change or examples of best practices

actual.value: Through project meetings and workshops a lot of emphasis has already been made on ensuring that gender and disadvantaged group interest will be mainstreamed in all interventions. We are analysing what gender issues our partners are facing when implementing practice-based and competence-based education and will then develop practical approaches to address these.

title.narrative: A.E.3. Number of staff that have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes

comment.narrative: 09-12-2020: 8 staff have been exposed to Dutch training methods and partners and have been part of the team discussions on curriculum content and didactics. Training will commence in Q4 2020.

title.narrative: A.E.1. Number of (knowledge) institutions supported directly

comment.narrative: 09-12-2020: Besides visiting the NL and local farms, capacity development of the organisations has not really started yet. | 09-12-2020: IABC, MMU, ADRAA and Muni university have been supported in terms of the exposure they have had in the Netherlands where they visited colleges and farms that are collaborating in vocational training.

title.narrative: A.E.2. Increased participation of students from minorities

comment.narrative: 09-12-2020: Participation is still zero as the pilot still needs to start. Selection of students will be done in Q4 2020.

title.narrative: A.S.3. Number of students performing an internship or practical work

comment.narrative: 19-01-2021: 4 students from So far two groups of students visited the project in Arua. In december 2019 A group of four students from Windesheim Honours College went for an introductory trip to Arua, Uganda to explore the project and region. Each year two groups of WHC students will travel to Arua with a clear assignment linked to the OKP project T4GJ. In January 2020 three students of van Hal Larenstein did research on elevation and drainage at the farm Kilimo Kisasa. The farm will be adapted into a hands-on learning environment for the students participating in T4GJ's new curriculum. Due to Covid the next groups will probably be able to travel to Uganda not sooner than spring 2021.
female students should also be indicated.

title.narrative: A.E.6. Number of students enrolled in revised/newly developed study programmes

comment.narrative: 19-01-2021: Enrollment has been postponed and we expect 6 students to enroll in the pilot by March 2021.

comment.narrative: 19-01-2021: Muni university has a gender policy in place

title.narrative: A.S.2. Number of MoUs or other types of collaboration agreements signed (education, private, public, surrounding community)

comment.narrative: 19-01-2021: No formal agreements are in place yet. We expect to fomalise at least 4 MoUs in the coming year..

title.narrative: A.R.3. Number of relevant innovations

comment.narrative: 19-01-2021: Not applicable for this period. We expect to introduce new irrigation systems in the region. | 19-01-2021: not yet applicable. We expect to introduce irrigation and a number of techniques applied by the NIGI project that support cost-effective simple improvements in vegetable farming.

comment.narrative: 19-01-2021: We are still in the developing stage. We hope to reach many through the OKP and the projects that will are linked to OKP such as NIGI (see picture), IKEA and our WUR research projects.
